handNote.p: Ker describes the hand as 'skilful, small but clear, fluent and well-spaced'. A fluent late Anglo-Saxon miniscule with many caroline letterforms interchanging with insular ones, giving the impression of a speedy, less-calligraphic scribe. According to Ker, 'insular g is used for the spirant and caroline g for the stop'. Caroline tall s which may descend below the line; second tall s usually increasing in height when doubled. Two-stroke a usually roofed. Descenders typically curl to the left. Accents frequent and typically in a bowed shape. Descender of both forms of g has a diagonal finishing stroke. The top of f and s, and st-ligature, drawn with two strokes, frequently resulting in a vertical 'horn' extending from the left-hand side of the top bows of these forms. A doubled-thorn abbreviation for 'þæt þæt' in use. Corrections made both using a mark of insertion (usually a bit curved) or unmarked supralinear writing.
